original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.
simplified:
Dreams are like stories or pictures in your head when you sleep.

Sometimes, dreams come from our mind. Our mind thinks about things from the day. But dreams have a special meaning. When we are not sleeping, we think with words. It is like we talk to ourselves. But when we are sleeping, our brain changes. The part for words works less. The part for feelings works more.

original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.
simplified: Perhaps dreams are the result of our mind organizing the thoughts we have during the day. But these thoughts appear in dreams with special meaning. When we are awake, our thoughts usually appear in our minds as words. They are like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we are asleep, the language part of our brain becomes less active, while the emotion part of our brain becomes more active.

original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.
simplified: Good relationships make people happy. A relationship is how you are with other people. One study showed this. Most happy people had good friends and family. They spent time with them often. You also need at least one person. You can share your true feelings with this person. This is a very deep talk. One person for these deep talks is enough. You also need other relationships. It is not enough to have many friends. It is not enough to just do things with them. It is not enough to talk about music or football. You need a deeper relationship with people. This deeper relationship is very important. Some people need to learn to listen well. This helps them make stronger relationships.

original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.
simplified: Having good **relationships**, which are the connections you have with people like friends or family, is a big part of feeling happy. In one study, it was discovered that most happy people had strong ties to their friends and family, and they spent time with them often. You also need at least one person who you can talk about your personal feelings with. Just one person for a deep conversation is enough, but it is also good to have a group of other friends. It is not enough to have many friends just to do things with or to talk about music or football. That deeper connection is very important. Some people need to learn how to listen well to others so that they can build stronger relationships.

original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
simplified:
Carol Dweck is a psychologist. She studies the mind. She talks about a 'growth mindset'. This means you believe you can learn. You believe you can get better. She says our brain has plasticity. This means our brain can change. We can learn new skills and talents. Maybe we are not good at them at first.

Many people praise the final result. They also praise innate talents. This means talents you are born with. People think these talents are natural. For example, they say, 'You are good at seeing small things.' Or, 'You are good at organising events.'

But studies show a different way. We should praise the process. This is how people do things. Praise their hard work. Praise experimentation. This means trying new things. Praise their ways to solve problems. This praise helps people learn new skills. It helps them hone their talents. This means making them better.

original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
simplified: Carol Dweck, who is an expert on the mind, talked about the brain's ability to change. She believed in a 'growth mindset', which is the idea that we can develop skills and natural abilities, even if we were not good at them at first. Many of us often praise the final result and abilities that seem natural. For example, we might say, 'You are good at seeing details' or 'You have a natural ability for organising events'. However, research suggests something important. We can help people develop new skills and make their natural abilities even better. This happens if we focus on the *process* of how things are done. For example, we can praise their hard work, their attempts to try new things, and their ways of solving problems.

original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.
simplified:
A rover looks at the air on Mars. It does this often.
In 2014, the rover found a gas in the air. This gas is methane.
Methane is a very simple gas. It is a basic part of life. It is also in natural gas.
Methane does not stay for a long time. It only stays for a few hundred years.
This shows that something on Mars makes more methane all the time.
NASA says Mars sends out thousands of tons of methane at a time.
The amount of methane goes up and down. This happens at different times of the year.
It is like the planet Mars takes air in and out.

original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.
simplified: The rover regularly checks the air around it, and in 2014, it discovered `methane` in the air. `Methane` is a simple natural gas and an important part of natural gas, but it only stays for a few hundred years. This shows that something on Mars must be making more of it. NASA says that Mars sends out thousands of tons of `methane` at one time, and the amount of `methane` goes up and down at different times of the year, almost as if the planet is breathing.

original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.
simplified:
Carol Dweck is a psychologist. She works at Stanford University. She did a test when she started her job. She gave problems to ten-year-old children. The problems were a little bit too hard for them.

One group of children was happy. They said they liked to try hard things. They knew they could learn and get better. She said these children had a 'growth mindset'. This means they believed they could always learn. They thought about what they can do in the future.

But another group of children felt people judged them. They felt people judged if they were smart. They felt they did not do well. She said these children had a 'fixed mindset'. This means they believed they could not get better. They could not imagine learning more.

Some children said they might copy answers later. Other children looked for someone. This person did worse than them. They wanted to feel good about themselves.

original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.
simplified: At the start of her working life, Carol Dweck, a scientist who studies the mind at Stanford University, gave some ten-year-old children problems that were a little too hard for them. One group reacted well; they said they loved the challenge, which is something difficult but interesting, and they understood that their abilities could develop. She says these children had a 'growth mindset', which is a way of thinking where you believe you can get better, and they focused on what they could achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that someone was judging how clever they were, and they did not succeed. These children had a 'fixed mindset', which is a way of thinking where you believe your abilities cannot change, and they could not think about getting better. Some of them even said they might act dishonestly in the future, while others looked for someone who had done worse than them to make themselves feel better.

original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.
simplified: Scary films love empty places. These places can be an old hospital. They can be an empty house. Or they can be an old town with no people. There is something special about these empty places. You think about the people who lived there. Why did they leave? These places are very quiet. This can be scary too. Film makers like these places for another reason. It is easy to believe your phone does not work there.

original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.
simplified: Horror films often use places where no one lives, such as an old hospital that no one uses, a scary empty house, or a town where no one lives anymore. There is something special about these lonely and empty places, and people often wonder what it was like when others lived there, and why they left. Also, these places are often very quiet, which can be scary too. And for directors of scary films, these abandoned places are useful because it is easier to believe that there will be no phone signal there.

original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.
simplified: A basement is a room under a house. In scary films, basements are scary places. Something often hides there. Or bad people put their tools there. Basements are always dark. They are often wet. You can only get to them by a small stair. Basements are always scary. This is true even if nothing is there.

original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.
simplified: Basements are always scary places in horror films, no matter what type of house it is. This is usually where something is hiding, or where a bad `psychopath` has put their tools. A `psychopath` is a person with a serious mental illness that makes them act in a violent or dangerous way. Basements are always dark and often wet, and you can only get to them by a small staircase. Also, they are always creepy, even when nothing is there.

original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.
simplified:
Gary Collins was a policeman.
He was not working.
He watched the London trouble in the city on TV.
He saw some people he knew very fast.
He stopped his holiday early.
He wanted to help find these people.
He looked at camera videos for six months.
He found 190 people.
He knew many people just from their eyes.
His help was very important for the police work.
There were 200,000 hours of video.
A computer program looked at faces.
But it found only one person.

original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.
simplified: Gary Collins was a policeman who was not working when he saw the London riots on TV. He recognised some people right away, so he ended his holiday early to help the police identify them. He spent six months watching the video film from CCTV cameras, and he was able to identify 190 people. Many of these people he recognised just from their eyes. His help was very important for the police investigation, because even with 200,000 hours of video, a computer program for facial recognition only identified one person.

original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.
simplified: I think this is very interesting. We can make ourselves change faster. We can make our bodies better. Imagine putting a computer inside our brain. Soon, we can do this. We can make our maths ability better. We can make our ability to see and hear better. We can make our memory better. This idea will be very common.

original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.
simplified: I think it's fascinating to consider how we can speed up our **evolution**, which is the way living things change and develop over a long time, by making our bodies better. Soon we will be able to put a computer inside our brain. This will make our maths skills, seeing and hearing, and memory better. This idea will then become more and more usual.

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
simplified:
The talk was very good. The person talking said many true things.
Think about parents. Parents use social media when they cook. They use it when they wait for the traffic light. Young people see this. So, how can we ask young people to not text when they do homework?
She also said people want to be in many places at the same time. They talk in real life. They also talk online. They change quickly between these.
I see this often. My young daughter and her friends do this. They plan to meet. Then they sit together. They do not talk to each other. Each one talks to different people online.

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
simplified: The talk was very interesting, and the speaker said something exactly right about a few things. For example, she talked about how parents affect their children. She said that we cannot expect young people not to text while doing their homework, because they often see their parents putting things on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light. She also made a good point about people who want to do many things at the same time. Because of this, they often move quickly between their real conversations and talking online. I often see this with my young daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, but then they sit together without talking, because each one is talking to different people online.

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified:
News stories make us think the world has more fighting now. But there is also some good news.
From the end of World War II to 1990, 30 wars happened. These wars killed more than 100,000 people.
Today, there are still civil wars. But most countries live together more peacefully now. This is better than in the past.
But terrorism went up a lot in the last few years. Since World War II, wars killed many more civilians than soldiers.
But for civilians, the numbers are not all bad. People die more from violent crime. This is nine times more than from problems about power in a country.
The number of murders around the world fell a little. In 2000, 8 people died for every 100,000 people. In 2015, it was about 5.3 people.

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified: Although news stories often make us think that the world is becoming more dangerous, there is also some hope. For example, between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today, there are still civil wars, but countries are generally living together more peacefully than they did in the past. However, **terrorism**, which is violence that causes fear, often for political reasons, has increased quickly in the last few years. Also, since World War II, wars have killed many more **civilians**, who are people not in the army, than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the facts are not all bad, because deaths are nine times more likely to be from dangerous crime than from fighting between groups or countries. In fact, the worldwide number of murders went down a little, from 8 for every 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified:
`Human rights` are rules. They say all people should be treated well. Everyone has these rights.

Wasfia spent her life `supporting human rights`. She saw many `humanitarian projects` from other countries. These projects taught and trained women and girls in her country. But these projects stopped. This happened too many times. Then the women and girls had nothing.

Wasfia saw this problem. She `thought` Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself. She had two strong loves. One was `climbing` mountains. The other was `human rights`. She `joined` these two loves together. She wanted to change how people feel about women in her country.

She started `climbing` mountains. She was doing `humanitarian work` in Tibet and Nepal then. Bangladesh is a flat country near the sea. Most people there never saw a mountain.

Her plan seems to be `doing the trick`. People in her country are starting to notice. People in other countries are also noticing.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified: Humanitarian projects are projects that help people who are suffering, for example, because of war or natural disasters. Wasfia has given her life to supporting human rights, and she has seen many of these projects in her home country. These projects educate and train women and girls, but too many times, when the projects stopped continuing, the women were left with nothing. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to help itself, so she combined two things she loves: mountain climbing and human rights. She did this to try and change how people think about women in her country. She started climbing when she was working on humanitarian projects in Tibet and Nepal, because Bangladesh is a country near the sea and it is mostly flat, so most people there have never seen a mountain. Her project seems to be working well, as people from her country are paying attention, and the rest of the world is noticing too.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
simplified:
Most people think poor countries are in a very bad situation.
People in these countries are very poor.
Bad leaders rule them.
People think there is little hope for good change.
But this is not true.
A big change is happening.
In the last 20 years, 700 million people got more money.
They are not poor now.
Also, six million fewer children die from sickness every year.
Many more girls go to school.
Many people now have clean water.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.

However, this is far from the truth. In reality, a great transformation is happening. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and have left poverty. In addition, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are now in school, and millions of people can get clean water.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified:
Managers want to make their feedback positive.
Many managers use a special way. They put bad feedback between two good comments. This is like a sandwich.
But managers do this often. It becomes a normal way to give feedback.
Then, people start to think in a new way.
They think good comments just make bad things seem good.
So, people do not believe the good feedback. It loses its worth.
Good feedback should not just hide bad things.
It should make good work stronger and help people do it more.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Managers often try to make their **feedback** (which means comments and advice about someone's work) sound more positive by putting negative comments between two positive ones. However, when this becomes a normal way to give **feedback**, employees might start to think that the positive comments are just a way to hide the bad news, so the positive **feedback** loses its value. Instead, positive **feedback** should not just be used to make negative comments softer, but it should be given to support and encourage good work.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified:
I am in a group. It is called 'Campaign to Stop Killer Robots'. We want to stop these robots.
Do not think about film robots. They are scary. They step on heads. This is not real.
Instead, think about real robots now.
Military machines already kill people. These are like drones. They are like robots with guns. They are like robots that watch places. People control them very little.
The next thing will be 'murderbots'. These robots will kill people. They will get orders. But they will choose who to kill by themselves.
I think this is very wrong. It is dangerous for all people.
We must be very, very careful about what we ask machines to do.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified: I am a member of the Campaign to Stop **Killer Robots**, which are machines that can decide to kill people by themselves. We should not think about scary movie robots, like the Terminator, but instead, we need to think about what is happening now. For example, army machines such as drones, gun turrets, and guard robots are already being used to kill people with very little help from humans. The next step will be robots that kill on their own, and these robots will follow orders but decide who to kill by themselves. I believe that this would be completely wrong and dangerous for all people, so we need to be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
simplified:
Your boss stops you. She wants to talk about your work. It is about the last project. She wants to talk about your performance. You feel bad all weekend. You worry about the project. You think: "Did I do something wrong?"
On Monday, you go to her office. She says good things about your work first. You think: "Is this the good talk she has to say first?" You think: "Is she going to say her real message next?" This way of talking is like a sandwich. First, people say good things. Then, they say what they really think. Then, they say good things again.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified:
"Born in the USA" is a rock album. The music is fast. Your feet move to the music. These are very strong songs. But the words have strong feelings. They carry emotional weight.

The music has catchy rock melodies. But the songs tell stories about the bad side of the "American dream." The American dream means everyone in America can get rich and be happy if they work hard.

Many songs are about normal people. These people work hard. They feel sad and very angry. Life does not give them money or great success.

For example, "Glory Days" is about people in a small town. They remember their young days. They felt the world was at their feet. "Downbound Train" is about a young man. His life becomes very bad. He loses his job.

It is easy to think the artist writes about real people he knew. Maybe he writes about his own life too. What if he was not a star? You will know about his very special skill. People call him 'the Boss'.

The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. For example, 'Glory Days' is about people in a small town remembering their youth, while 'Downbound Train' tells the story of a young man whose life becomes very bad when he loses his job. The album will clearly show you the special and great talent of the Boss.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified:
Lewis wants more marine protected areas. These are special places in the sea where nature is safe. Now, 3 out of 100 sea areas are protected. Lewis wants 10 out of 100 areas to be protected. He wants to stop the damage people do. People catch too many fish. This is called overfishing. People also make the sea dirty. They throw waste in the sea.

Lewis went on many trips. He saw the damage to the natural world by himself. He swam over coral reefs. The water got hotter. This made the reefs white. This is called bleaching. He saw places under the Red Sea. They were like deserts. There was no life. There was a lot of plastic waste.

Pugh thinks the natural world can get better. It needs space to do this. But time is going fast. If we do not look after our seas now, we will soon have a problem. We cannot fix this problem.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified: Lewis wants to see more marine protected areas in the world. He would like the number to increase from 3% to 10%. This is to stop the damage caused by human activities like overfishing, polluting, and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental damage first-hand. He has swum over **coral**, which is a hard, colourful material made by small sea animals. This coral has lost its colour because the water got hotter. He also saw underwater deserts beneath the not deep waters of the Red Sea. These places had no life and were covered with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have a problem we cannot fix on our hands.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified:
Terrie Sharp is a writer. Her books are very popular. She tells good stories. She won a prize two times. It was the Olive Crime Writer Award.

She was born in Glasgow. She lived in an area of houses. Many bad things happened there. She learned to be quiet. She learned to stay out of problems. She learned to open car doors with a knife.

But she did this only for her books. Now she is not quiet. She is on TV shows like Police Today. She goes to writer meetings. She goes to meetings in all parts of the UK.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified: Terrie Sharp is a very popular writer who knows how to tell good stories, and she has won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times. She was born in Glasgow, in a place with many houses where there was a lot of crime, so she learned to be quiet, avoid problems, and even how to open car doors using a knife. Luckily, she only used these skills for her books, but now she is not quiet, and she appears on popular TV shows, like 'Police Today', and at writing meetings all over the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified:
Are things bad every day? Can things not get better?

Steven Pinker wrote a book. Its name is "Enlightenment Now". He looks at the whole story of humans. He says there is good news. He says humans are getting better.
We live longer. We are healthier. We are freer. We are happier.

But Pinker says there is a problem. He says people are attacking Enlightenment ideas. These ideas are about reason and science. The Enlightenment was a time when people started to think more about science and reason.

Some leaders and speakers talk to people. They make people only care about their own group. They make people think things cannot get better. They make people not trust others.
This can cause very bad damage. This damage cannot be fixed. This can hurt important groups. For example, it can hurt democracy. A democracy is when people choose their leaders. It can also hurt when countries work together.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified: Many people ask if things are getting worse every day, or if it is impossible for us to make progress. However, in his book 'Enlightenment Now', Steven Pinker looks at how humans have developed and finds good news. He says that we are now living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. Pinker believes that the real problem is that people are attacking the values of the Enlightenment, which was a time in history when people started to believe more in reason and science. Some people, like news reporters or powerful leaders, try to make others feel very loyal to their own group. They might also make people believe that they cannot change things or not trust others. If this happens, we are in danger. This can cause serious damage to important systems like democracy, where people choose their leaders by voting, and to countries working together.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified: In old horror films, the main people were very scared. They could not call for help. They could not call the police. Now, mobile phones make this hard to believe. So, how can films keep people excited? The answer is: phones do not work! If you are a hero in a horror film, you will need to call for help. This happens at an important time. But your phone will almost certainly not work. Or your phone battery will die. This happens when you start to call. Sometimes, both things happen.

If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified: In older horror films, the main characters often found it difficult or impossible to call for help or the police when they were in a very bad situation. However, mobile phones have made this situation less easy to believe today. So, to keep the excitement, films often show that there is no phone signal. If you are a hero in a horror film, you will almost certainly find that at an important moment, when you really need to call for help, you will not have any signal. Also, your phone battery might die just as you are trying to make the call, or both things could happen.

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified:
In the 1950s, banana companies in Central America had a big problem. Their `Gros Michel banana` was dying. This banana made them the most money. People called it Big Mike.

Now, the same problem is happening again. It is happening to the `Cavendish` banana. The `Cavendish` banana replaced Big Mike.

The `Gros Michel banana` was a fruit. It was easy to move. It had thick skin. It tasted sweet. This banana grew on many big farms in Central America. It was the most important banana there.

United Fruit was a big company. It was the main company for bananas in South America. It grew bananas. It also sent them to other countries. This company grew many, many bananas. They had the best way to grow them. They took small parts from the plant stems. These were exact copies. They did not grow them from seeds. They grew many plants very close together in the fields.

And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.

And now, the same problem is happening again to the Cavendish, which is the banana that came after Big Mike. The Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations in Central America because its fruit was easy to transport, had thick skin, and tasted sweet. United Fruit, which was the main company growing and selling bananas in South America at that time, produced a very large number of bananas in the most efficient way possible. They did this by taking new plants from the stems of existing plants instead of growing them from seeds, and they planted them very close together in the fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified:
Most spiders have venom. Venom is a special liquid. They use it to stun or kill their food. They do not use it to attack people.

Only 25 known types of spiders have venom that can truly harm people. Spider bites can hurt. But they almost never kill people.

The Sydney funnel-web spider is a very dangerous spider from Australia. It has not killed anyone since 1981. This is because anti-venom was made in 1981. Anti-venom is a special medicine for venom.

Be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. Do not make them angry. When they feel danger, they protect themselves. They throw out special hairs that make you itch. These hairs can stick in your skin or eyes.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified:
Most kinds of spiders have **venom**, which is a poisonous liquid. Its purpose is to stun or kill the animals they hunt, and not to attack people. In fact, only 25 known kinds of spiders produce venom that can really harm humans. Although their bites can be painful, they are not often deadly. For example, Australia's Sydney funnel-web spider, which is famous for being dangerous, has not killed anyone since an anti-venom was developed in 1981.

However, you should be careful not to make hairy spiders, like tarantulas, angry. When they feel they are in danger, they protect themselves by sending out a cloud of **urticating hairs**, which are irritating hairs. These hairs then stick into the skin or eyes of the attacker.

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified:
This is a common story in scary films. Many scary films had this story. It was very popular in the past, around the year 2000.
The film starts with a group of teenagers. They are having fun. Everyone dies, except one girl.
At first, the girl is usually good. She does not do bad things. She is shy. She is not very strong. Later, she becomes the toughest person. She is very good at knowing how to win. She is the best in the world. The last girl almost always wins.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
We want to know where our language with many parts came from. We must look at our brains. Our brains are different from animal brains. It is not just about how big our brains are. It is important what our brains can do. And when and why they became like this over a long time.
We have few clues about this. Old tools from people who lived long ago. These tools do not tell us how they could speak. But we can see old bones. We can see how the mouth, throat, and tongue changed. They became better for speaking. About 100,000 years ago, people's bodies slowly changed to make difficult sounds. Before that, scientists who study how people changed can only guess. Did early people use very simple sounds to talk?

And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: If we want to know where our ability for complex language started, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This is about more than just brain size, but it is also important to know what other things our brains can do, and when and why they developed in that way. However, there are very few physical signs for this; for example, objects left by early humans do not tell us what kind of speech they could make. One thing we can see in the bones of early humans, however, is how their mouth, throat, and tongue developed. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had developed the ability to make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists who study how living things change over time can only guess whether early humans talked using more basic sounds.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified:
Society tells us this. Nature does not tell us this.
Society says girls should do arts and humanities. Society says boys should do maths and physics.
Also, young people do not see many good female role models in jobs about science.
Cartoons and stories often show men as scientists. These men are crazy. Or they are a genius inventor. Or they are an adventurous astronaut. These are always men.
People also have wrong ideas about scientists. These are wrong ideas about people.
People think scientists are geeky. They think scientists are not good at talking to people. They think scientists work alone. They think scientists are not part of the world.
Media shows these wrong ideas. This can mean girls do not feel like scientists. They do not want science as a job.
If girls saw more good female role models in science, they would feel more sure about themselves. They would feel more like they are part of these school subjects.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: It is society, not how we are born, that often tells girls they should prefer arts and subjects like history, and leave maths and physics to boys. Also, young people do not see enough positive female `role models`, who are people you admire and want to be like, doing jobs connected to science. For example, cartoons and stories often show the strange scientist or clever inventor as a man. There is also a wrong belief that scientists are geeky, which means they are only interested in science and computers. People also think that scientists are not good at talking to others, or that their work is lonely and separate from the rest of the world. These are false `stereotypes`, which are fixed ideas about what a type of person is like, shown by the media. But these ideas can mean that girls do not feel similar to scientists, and they see science as a job that does not seem interesting. If girls saw more positive female `role models` in science, it would give them more belief in themselves and make them feel more like they fit in these subjects.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.

The Scallion is a newspaper. Students print it every week. It is free. You can get it in university buildings. About 10,000 students read it. Students write this newspaper. Students make it.
A study shows the newspaper is very important. Students and university workers think it is important for fun. It helps them learn about culture. It helps them learn about work.
Printing the newspaper costs a lot of money. Also, some students cannot get the newspaper easily. You must go to the university to get one. Another problem is for nature. Many copies become trash. They are on the university area.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified:
A `turnover` is when people leave their jobs. New people start.
A `retention` is when people stay in their jobs.
`Employee engagement` means workers like their jobs and want to work hard.

At Girox Foods, our employee `turnover` is about 12% every year. This means 12 people out of 100 leave. The usual number for companies like ours is 7%. So, our `turnover` is high.

The main aim of this report is to find out why workers feel `employee engagement`. The report will offer ideas. These ideas will make the workers' experience at work better. They will help with `retention`. More workers will stay at Girox Foods.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, we have an `employee turnover` of about 12% each year. This is the number of employees who leave the company. Although this might not seem high when you first look, the normal level for this industry is 7%. The main aim of this report is to look into the reasons for `employee engagement` in the company. `Employee engagement` means how interested and involved employees are in their work. We will use what we find. From this, we will suggest ways to make employees feel better about their place of work and to keep more employees.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.

This is not such a big problem for my generation, because we lived without technology for a long time. We know how to be alone, and we also know that it is okay to be alone. original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified:
`Feedback` is when you tell someone what you think about their work. It can be good or bad.

Don't always give good feedback and then bad feedback. If you always do this, the good feedback seems less important. People will not listen to it. So, sometimes, give only good feedback. Don't give bad feedback at these times.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: You should not always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the good things can seem less important and be ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given just to be positive, and do not give constructive criticism at these times.
